name: Eldritch Reanimated
description: Eldritch is the original imsim roguelike: a first-person action game inspired by roguelikes, immersive sims, and H. P. Lovecraft.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 150 MB available space

reviews.review_text: I don't think I've had this large a change of heart on a game in a long while. Going into Eldritch, I lost hope almost immediately. A combination of mediocre voxel environments, cartoonish bad guys, goofy sound effects, and stab-happy gameplay just didn't really jive with the whole Lovecraftian aesthetic it claimed to be rocking. Thirty minutes in I'd realized I'd come across pretty much every item I was going to see. An hour in and I'd conquered the first world, having at no time felt threatened by anything I faced. I entered world 2 for a few minutes, finding more of the same. Apart from my grudging admiration for the simple-yet-effective 3D minimap the game uses, I came to the conclusion that there was nothing here worth playing any further for. Bored and angry, I set the game aside for a while, wondering why anyone would publish so straightforward and sloppy a first-person shooter and decide to slap a Lovecraft theme on it.  Coming back to it on a whim, I re-entered world 2 and dug a little deeper. Suddenly, things were different. The difficulty spiked up nicely, adding opponents that required actual strategy, that I couldn't just flail wildly at and never worry about again, that left me feeling more than a little nervous. And then I died, though I'm not exactly sure how. I rushed back in, suddenly stripped of all my magic armaments and life boosts, and last less than half as long. Eventually, I figured out what's going on, learned how to dodge the traps, realized that stealth and discretion are actually necessary to survive, and on I went to a fun, twitchy, jumpy run through the rest of this Eternal Darkness / Spelunky / Minecraft hybrid. It's not terribly deep; as I said earlier, you find the vast majority of the items you'll ever see in level 1, and while the monsters do evolve over time, there's not a huge amount of variety here. Oftentimes, new monsters will simply be beefier and shoot faster, but there's enough weirdness thrown in to keep the game fresh. Also, be aware that this is in fact a roguelike. Dying sets you back to the start with just short of all your progress erased, but thankfully this is a game which rewards knowledge every bit as much as it does lots of ammo and a pair of stealth boots.  Don't go into this expecting any kind of dignified cosmic horror experience. It's sloppy, it's fun, and it's got some nice retro vibes to it hearkening back to the first person shooters of yore. If you're not sure if Eldritch is going to be for you, gauge your reaction to the phrase, 'Cthulhu vs. the Ninja Assassin.' If that mental image doesn't ♥♥♥♥ you off, well hey, here's your chance to see it in action.

A game that presents you with everything you need from the start, and casually waits for you to learn its rules. It's a really refreshing time, and a pretty player friendly entry point into the roguelike/immersive sim genre. Levels are procedurally generated, but work from established tile sets that lead to familiar feeling levels; despite their randomized nature. It never feels unfair. The progression curve just feels really great. Definitely check this game out.

Also, you'll do everything to don't die. Every life matters.  All in all, Eldritch it's a game to be played slowly. Keep in mind that there's not much action here. Instead, there's a lot of tense moments and a great feeling of satisfaction when you can finish a stage alive.  How long can you survive in this hostile world?

Eldritch is a great game   Gameplay is tough, but fun: initially pretty hard (and terrifying), but becomes easier once you're familiar with the enemies and level layouts. Plays a little like a 3D version of Derek Yu's Spelunky, but that's a poor comparison. Involves a nice blend of action with stealth (required on the later levels). Roguelike elements - level generation, item placement etc. makes each run feel fresh. Graphics are really nice, particularly the enemy models, and the atmospheric music and sounds are perfect.  Whilst the main levels are pretty short, it'll take you some time to actually finish them. The new game+ mode is challenging even for veterans. The two 'bonus' levels offer a great amount of additional playtime: a super-long level and a challenge level, that you will be playing again and again to get that 500 souls achievement. The inspiration from lovecraft is a nice touch, especially since I'm a fan of his works (although the relationship to his original literature is pretty weak).   Overall: Excellent game, fun with a lot of replayability.   Also contains achievements that are damn near impossible. I'LL 100% IT ONE DAY, MARK MY WORDS.

Eldritch is one of the finest examples I have seen of a game that has both simplicity and complexity harnessed in exactly the right measures. The result is a game that is both infintely enjoyable and completely understandable, which is a real rarity. When you couple that with the incredibly well-executed theme, and the sheer polished feel to the whole thing, Eldritch has earned itself a slot on my shelf of all-time-favorites.  The concept is simple: get to the bottom, stay alive, retrieve the thing. But along the way, so many things can go so horribly, horribly wrong that the sense of satisfaction when you finally put your hand on your goal(s) is profound. Each world playes by its own rules and demands different approaches, while everything is at the same time built upon a consistent, understandable basis. Amazing. This is rogue-like done extraordinarily well.  And, it's got Shoggoths. What's not to love.

An FPS adventure which will keep you on your toes.  Difficulty curve grows a bit oddly in the main game, it's an issue which has been taken care of in Mountains of Madness (MoM) -expansion's content. Also, the main game in normal mode is beat quite fast. That being said, 'New Game+' mode is for those who won't be satisfied after their first playthrough.   The main game consists of an usual playthrough and a more story-driven, a tad more difficult one ingrained within the game world. I won't go any further on that, since one will come across it and eventually decide the way they will continue on: rest assured you will find this to be an enjoyable aspect. MoM's progression is more straight-forward on the other hand, it's flavour coming from challenges thrown at the player as ventured forwards.  Another thing worth mentioning is the soundtrack. Not many other games have so brilliant ambient sounds, consisting of droning electric guitar walls, to create such a gloomy atmosphere. If the graphics and gameplay won't bring up Lovecraft, the soundscape of the game will.

Recommended. The game has its flaws, but they are overshadowed by its successes.  Before I begin, you should know that I do not play many first-person shooters, and almost no horror games to speak of. Eldritch is not a 'horrror' game per se, but seeks to encourage a similar atmosphere and as such was a newer experience to me than it might be for many others.  Eldritch is a strange combination of Lovecraftian horror and first-person-shooter that somehow managed to blend its disparate elements together very well.  Anything with a Lovecraftian atmosphere should attempt to mimic the tone and atmosphere of its inspiration - the entire point of which was to make the reader feel not only helpless and hopeless, but utterly insignificant. First-person-shooters, on the far end of the spectrum, are most often about empowering the player to often absurd levels, though recently the trend has been to take a more 'realistic' disempowering approach.  If you're willing to jump into the game with your eyes closed - which is easy, as the trailer gives off the entirely wrong atmosphere - the game can begin as very disempowering, and even very unsettling. The use of FOV, lighting, background noise and uncanny help to establish a horror setting early, but still leave the player plenty of room to maneuver. The feeling of uneasiness is sadly fleeting for most of the game, however. Once you learn how the stealth system works and how the enemy AI reacts, most of the game is actually fairly easy. The 'eldritch abominations' usually die with a few whacks from a knife or shots from a pistol, and an easily-locatable backpack item lets you revive as many times as you have enough artifacts (in-game currency) to afford. Towards the end of the game, presuming you have the presence of mind to find the three special (useless) equipment items, the tone shifts toward disempowerment again. Some enemies will either be very strong or downright invincible, and once you're no longer able to slip past them like a whisper or revive yourself after death, the feeling of uneasiness returns as you realize that it will only take a few mistakes to end the game. Usually, that is not a terrible consequence, but because dying in Eldritch results in having to start over from the beginning, it (often) means losing hours of progress. This was a good design choice, I think, because it makes the closing of the game difficult and forces the player to adopt extra caution in their movements.   This game is not the strongest example of first-person-shooting, exploration, Lovecraftian horror or even unease-inducing atmosphere on Steam. But it does each job well enough to blend into something interesting and, to my eyes at least, unique.

At first glance you may not expect the Lovecraftian atmosphere to be highly present, but it is. In particular, the mumbling of the cultists and the creepy breathing of the mummies sends a chill down my spine. You have to hide, observe your surroundings, and plan your next move if you want to survive.

It doesn't have a lot of depth, it's not always that scary, but chances are if you think you might be into it you will enjoy it. In that case, buy it. There are horror elements, and it CAN be scary. Those first few hours and every time you enter a new area, it is actually pretty creepy.  It's got elements of Dishonored, Deus Ex, Minecraft and a few more and they jell better than you may expect them to.  Just know it's not really a brutally difficult survival horror game.  It's a game that wants you to mess with its mechanics and see how you can exploit it, see how you can find a different way of getting around an obstable.  That lack of real depth does make it very accessible however, and the base gameplay is still fun. My only real issue with the game is the level generation doesn't always make the route the the exit easy, sometimes requiring TNT to bust your way through.  Note: If you are not finding it difficult enough, my best suggestion is to die and then try that same level again. Thanks to fountains and slowly accumulating resources, things do get easier as you keep playing. Each of the three areas you can unlock (possibly the expansions) is balanced for you having succeeded the previous one and accruing items from that. This does mean difficulty doesn't really raise more than slightly, although this may differ by your playstyle (Those ♥♥♥♥ing statues in the second area are brutal). Even just not having the Compass you get for free in the first area makes the game significantly harder.

If you're a fan of H.P. Lovecraft's mythos, or just enjoy some simple Roguelike exploration, Eldritch is 100% for you. Four worlds as of the time of this review, each one based upon various stories and beings within the Cthulhu mythos (including the infamous Mountains of Madness), brought to you in a Minecraft-style first person perspective. Randomly-generated procedural labyrinths, some rudimentary resource management, mystical powers, irritable shopkeepers, dungeon exploration, death traps, invincible Shoggoths... it's all there, watching. Waiting.  Welcome to the Library.

I'll keep this short and sweet: This is a rouge-like shooter with Lovecraftian themes. If you enjoy either of those things then purchase this. Purchase it right now.  It may look silly, graphically speaking, but this is NOT an easy game. It is harsh and unforgiving. And kind of terrifying when you get into it. So if you're looking for something casual then look elsewhere.  Graphics: 10/10 - They fit it perfectly, so far as I'm concerned. Audio: 9/10 - There's the occasional audio glitch for me, but it's nothing too terrible. Gameplay: 9/10 - I am a coward who wishes there was more carry-over between deaths. Story: 8/10 - It's delivered in the old school survival horror way (i.e. you find journal entries of deceased explorers). There isn't too much there, but it isn't needed.  Overall: 9/10.  Purchase this game while it's still half-off!

I have a particular interest in first-person realtime roguelike dungeon crawlers. If you've stuck around for that 8-word (or 5 combo-word) genre description, stick around for more because I'm gonna tell you what I think Eldritch does right and wrong by that genre.  I want to sing some praises of the game. Character Control - Lean (left and right), crouch, slide (run/crouch), mantle (ledge climb). As simple as these four mechanics are, I feel they are essential for making a player feel like they are actually interacting with the environment instead of just... sliding through it with WSAD and jump alone. Third person action games are practically all Prince of Persia with the amount of climbing you do, but first-person games rarely attempt much. I appreciate Eldritch's effort here.  Interesting Enemies - There are a couple that really force you to play differently, and one in a way that I had never seen in a game before. Others provide some fun flavor that's just enjoyable to interact with.  Stealth - Most roguelikes don't feature any meaningful stealth mechanic. Thanks to the character control, Eldritch is very rewarding of careful, thoughtful advancement through its mazes. Since your character has little HP and healing is not terribly common, remaining in control of how you advance is essential to a sense of agency in a game that is otherwise random.  Here are some Meh issues -  Uninteresting Enemies - Most of the enemies have a boring fireball attack as their only offense. They are also highly predictable when pursuing you.  Shops - Too sparse and expensive. The 'bank' system which allows you store the game's currency from life to life isn't easy enough to access to make spending money worthwhile, which is a shame because some of the items really improve the experience.  Length and Difficulty - After 5 hours and only 8 deaths, I beat Eldritch. After you learn the enemy behavior, deaths only result from stupid mistakes or unlucky coincidences, so it doesn't give that broad sense of growth and education that good roguelikes have. The game also allows you to collect orbs to unlock 'shortcuts' to the later dungeons (there are 3 to unlock), but to actually beat the game you have to collect all the orbs in a single life anyway. So the shortcuts are only practical for practice, not for actual progress. The result is that the length of the game feels artificial and tedious, rather than hard-earned and rewarding.  The Ending - Getting to the end of a roguelike typically takes a lot of effort and it's nice to feel like your effort is tracked somewhere or you have some incentive to... do better or something. Eldritch says 'you won and it's anticlimactic,' in not so many words.  Feature Light - The game feels a little hollow, probably as a result of lacking variety in the game mechanics, enemy, and level event variety. This makes me appreciate the control mechanics even more.  Anyway, I'm glad I played Eldritch. It's made me aware of problems I'd have never considered for my own interest in the genre and it had its moments of excitement and inspiration. I'll definitely continue to play Eldritch as they release more updates.

To think that I impulse-bought this in the last Steam sale... If I had only known I would enjoy it more than any of the big budget games I had been looking forward to I would have saved my money and bought a bunch of copies of Eldritch instead! If you're looking for a stealth-based, rogue-like with a heavy emphasis on 3D platforming and atmosphere, it doesn't get better than this. Most people look at a few screenshots, write it off as a Minecraft cash-in, and move on. The poor fools! They don't even know what they're missing!  One thing is true: the graphics are nothing special. They capture the very minimum of their subject and the surroundings. There are some nice color palettes though, and the blocky nature light is cast makes it very obvious if you can be seen or not. And although the textures are unimpressive, the random level design is just as fun to look at as it is to traverse. Thankfully the audio is spectacular. Echoed moans, gurgles, gasps follow you wherever you go and always make you wonder what's just below your feet. The minimalist soundtrack is just as compelling. Obviously it's not a toe-tapping good time, but it certainly puts you on edge and makes you feel... Well, weird.  'Weird' is really the name of the game here. This isn't meant to be made into a reaction compilation on your Let's Play channel. It focuses on the 'Weird Tales' aspect in favor of a more frightening experience. For those of you who have been waiting patiently for a Lovecraftian game to mean more than fishmen and tentacle monsters yelling 'Boo!', this won't impress you. Also I'm really sorry and you must be REALLY used to disappointment by now.  This kind of highlights the weakest part of Eldritch: Lovecraft's world is alien and incomprehensible, but rogue-likes are inherently games about monotony and understanding. To beat a rogue-like means minimizing risks, self-mastery, and knowledge, but Lovecraft is about inescapable, cosmic realities, where knowledge comes at a VERY high cost and these horrors can never be beat, only kept at bay.  Eldritch's greatest strength, the genuinly alien nature of the random levels, the strange monsters that can't always be killed, and the crushing atmosphere instantly undo the game the moment you know how to avoid all the traps and deal with all the monsters. The first playthrough is magical: learning all of the powers, items, weapons, traps, monsters, seeing all of these non-sensical worlds realized... It's all so daunting in a very Lovecraftian way. But when you start farming world 1 for artifacts, or you start gearing up for the harder worlds, it's already too late.  If you're someone who knows Lovecraft as that guy with the strange tenticle fetish, or you're someone who can put the Lovecraftian label aside and just take in the very dreary tone and solid rogue-like mechanics, then I'd pick this game up without hesitation. If you've been patiently waiting for the Mythos to finally be realized in a computer game, than you'll have to keep waiting.

Eldritch is a neat little First Person Action game with procedurally generated levels and a heavily HP Lovecraft themed setting. The player must simply navigat from one end of each stage to the other, fighting off various tentacled, disgusting, gibbering flavors of 'Oh god, kill it, kill it, kill it!'. Along the way, you find weapons and equipment and meat to aid your trek. The game strikes a good balance of risk versus reward through the gameplay. You can't take many hits without dying and healing gets a bit sparse later on, so caution is a necessity at all times, but without a good amount of excess exploration, you'll quickly run out of supplies. Monsters also drop items and respawn indefinitely, but charging out to kill things is always a bit risky. It helps to set a nice atmosphere that, while you have a lot of power over the obstacles you'll face, it doesn't take many mistakes to see you fail. It's a game that greatly rewards patience and caution, while swiftly punishes recklessness. This balance is highly reminiscent of Spelunky in the best ways. While the difficulty starts out a bit insultingly easy, it quickly ramps up into a perfect sweet spot of hectic tension. The selection of items and spells, however, could use a little work. I never really found myself deviating from the set of items I was using and quickly equipping myself with them each new playthrough. For this type of game, always having access to one's preferred loadout, seems a bit off. As a suggestion, perhaps equipment should wear out over time, forcing the player to make do with what they can scrounge up, which seems more suited to this type of game. As for the spells, I think there just need to be more that can compete with the utility of Materialize. I mean, come on. The musis is good, and doesn't interfere with the profoundly important cocktails of squaks and hisses emanating from potential nearby threats. The graphics are, well, modest. It's not exactly going to push the limits of anyone's system , but you can tell right away what everything is supposed to be. Well, not the monsters, but that's not really because of the graphics. One complaint I have to make is that the particle effects have an annoying linger about them, especially the one coming from the player's left hand at all times. I frequently found myself jumping, thinking I had seen something out of the corner of my eye, only to realize it was an errant particle from the trail I was leaving, which was a tad irritating. On the whole, there isn't really much content here, but what there is is very well made and fun to play. I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy Spelunky and other similar games.

I love Eldritch but the funny thing about it is that I was at first disappointed (I initially thought there would be more backstory/adventuring involved, but I had little understanding of the type of game it was at the time, so that’s on me and in no way should it throw anyone off from enjoying it!).    It’s only after putting 12+ hours into it that I now realize how great it is as far as rogue-likes are concerned. Sure, there’s perma-death but you’ll keep the cash-monies you had in your bank chest upon resurrecting/exiting then restarting. Also, if you’re new to this game the Mountains of Madness, Asylum and Halloween/Pumpkin additions were added after its release, for free!   There’s a good bit of strategy involved if you wish to beat the 3 missions (MoM, Asylum and of course the library the game takes place in). Pickaxes, dynamite and even a charm that gives the gun the ability to fire bullets that break the environment (all of which do it Minecraft-style) can be utilized to your advantage. You can even pick up different kinds of packs, like the med pack that can revive you upon death as long as you have 50 gem thingies (‘artifacts’ as the game puts it) to spend, and boots that can grant different abilities, like high jumping and speed.   Be warned, though the enemies may look ‘cute-ish’, they can be, and often are, downright deadly! And In keeping with the lore of Lovecraft and the retro/blocky graphics, the enemies look great in that classic, cheesy 50’s era way.   On a final note, though Eldritch is certainly humorous at times, it’s still a horror game at its core and it certainly does justice to the godfather of modern sci-fi/horror, the man and legend that started it all, H.P. Lovecraft --- R.I.P. good sir, you live on through us all!!

At the time of writing this I have unlocked the third book.  This game is...well...H.P. Lovecraft certainly rolls in his grave over it.  The enemies are scary...at first. After playing about a minute on a floor you get so used to them you're willing to run around and stab everything without any kind of fear. The only real enemies I ran across that stayed a danger were 'unkillable'-The Shoggoth and the Statues. The Statues act like carbon-copy Weeping Angels (which is scary, sure, but they don't activate unless you walk in front of them) and the Shoggoth is...just...It's a giant slime thing that can't be killed. Trap it in a hole and boom, safe.  TL;DR:  Pros:  - Enemies start off scary and dangerous  - Minimal issues with gathering resources  - Stealth actually WORKS.  Cons:  - Enemies quickly become repetitive and boring.  - Resources can be very scarce or be overabundant between floors.  - Stealth is really, REALLY pointless when enemies start gaining flight.  - Dagger too OP.

I'm a huge fan of metroidvania style games. I like a challenge. But games like Eldritch are damned annoying. If you die, you lose all progress except for any levels that you unlock and money that you've stored in the bank. Any cool items, spells, weapons or 'experience' upgrades are lost. So you might as well start over each time that you die. Oh and good luck finding that sweet combination of items, weapons and spells again: everything is re-randomized upon death. I died a couple of times not because of the difficulty of the monsters, but because of typical accidents that occur in FPS games: one step too far and falling off a ledge, dying instantly, for example. Or mis-judging the range of a monster's hit-box. This game is brutally unforgiving and falls into the same old mis-placed nostalgic hard-on for 'old school brutality' which was nothing but a shallow, cynical design by the developpers to get kids to spend more quarters. Not because of some mythical love of the gaming 'craft'. Pass on this if you have precious little time to waste. Get this game if you want to maintain your 'old school' gaming cred.
